title: English  (1861) Codex Sinaiticus Snyder Miller (1861) 2004 Remake
description:
The Codex Sinaiticus, a 4th-century manuscript, is among the oldest known complete copies of the Christian New Testament. Discovered by Constantin von Tischendorf in the mid-19th century at the Monastery of Saint Catherine on Mount Sinai, this manuscript has been pivotal in biblical scholarship.

In 1861, Henry Tompkins Anderson, an American scholar, embarked on translating the New Testament from its original Greek. His dedication culminated in a publication in 1864. Subsequently, Anderson revised his translation to incorporate readings from the Codex Sinaiticus, leading to the 1918 release titled "The New Testament Translated from the Sinaitic Manuscript Discovered by Constantine Tischendorf at Mt. Sinai." However, it's important to note that this work was not a direct translation of the Codex but rather a revision of Anderson's earlier translation, adjusted to align with some readings from the Sinaitic manuscript.

In 2004, Jackson Snyder undertook a project to make Anderson's translation more accessible to contemporary readers. This endeavor involved modernizing the language and formatting while striving to maintain the integrity of Anderson's original work. Snyder's version, titled "The New Testament: The H.T. Anderson Translation," offers readers a rendition of the New Testament that reflects the textual nuances of the Codex Sinaiticus, presented in a style attuned to modern sensibilities.

These translations underscore the enduring significance of the Codex Sinaiticus in biblical studies, providing insights into early Christian texts and informing contemporary interpretations of the New Testament.
